movie_review_blurb: There's something about the film's roving sympathy that gives it surprising depth, mocking and embracing its characters -- adults and kids -- in quick succession.

movie_title: Tim and Eric's Billion Dollar Movie (2012)

movie_review_blurb: Bully doesn't offer solutions, it raises awareness, and does so remarkably well.

The film is schmaltzy and very saccharine, so sweet it'll give you a toothache.
movie_title: The Odd Life of Timothy Green (2012)

movie_review_blurb: ...sincere without being schmaltzy, evocative without being arrogant and lively without being pretentious - well, without being too pretentious.

...the very definition of a character driven drama, the performances humbling in their power.

...Merciless and unforgiving at every turn, thoroughly British, creepy and beautiful even in the gloriously demented details.

...This is no vanity project, but a real, solid and legitimate piece of filmmaking.

movie_review_blurb: Girlfriend's Day is not a great film, but it occasionally works, especially due to Bob Odenkirk's performance at its heart.
Lost Cat Corona has some problems with character development, but ultimately is a pleasant enough journey through an area of New York underappreciated in cinema.

Shimmer Lake takes a simplistic story and breathes new life through the use of reverse storytelling, a beautiful muted color scheme, and strong performances from its cast.

movie_title: The Only Living Boy in New York (2017)

movie_review_blurb: Future '38 is a memorable adventure which perfectly reflects our time, as well as reminisces about the films and sensibilities of the past.

Human connections trump technology in social media drama.

movie_review_blurb: Docu explores Internet addiction and family relationships.

movie_title: The Rise and Rise of Bitcoin (2014)

Painfully cliched romcom is full of sex and profanity.

movie_review_blurb: This is an actors' movie through and through, with all of them pulling off the key emotional scenes magnificently.
movie_title: Precious: Based on the Novel Push by Sapphire (2009)

movie_review_blurb: Folman's use of animation permits an audience to engage with the events, such as they are recalled, in a way that the simple testimony of those involved could not achieve.
Make no mistake, this is a difficult film to watch - but it is also a surprisingly uplifting one.
Each of the storylines wash over one another, refusing to take on a fully-fledged shape and yet they have a surprisingly cohesive cumulative effect.
Jim Carrey's latest is a perfectly pleasant if predictable picture about a part-time pop who learns his priorites after receiving a package of penguins.
The scriptwriters subsitute volume for humour, labouring under the misapprehension that if the animals yell at one another a lot it'll have us rolling in the aisles.
If ever there was a critic-proof film, this is most certainly it - but, pleasingly, it's so good that it doesn't have to be.
movie_title: Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows - Part 2 (2011)

movie_review_blurb: Touching but never mawkish and with a steely point to make.

Billed as something of a horror movie, the shifting sands of its tone make it neither fish nor fowl, as Smith flirts with comedy, action and horror without carrying off any of them particularly convincingly.
Angels Crest has a number of peripheral problems, mostly to do with the sheer number of under-developed characters and subplots.

Lucy Walker's chilling documentary serves as a reminder that the threat of a nuclear bomb going off somewhere in the world to devastating effect has not diminished just because it has slipped from the public consciousness.
Silver offers no easy way out of his moral maze, just an unflinching look at conflict and its impact both on the perpetrators and those who watch.

Connolly and Raymond capture both the pressure and joy of practice and performance and include plenty of footage of the teenagers simply going about the process of growing up and learning to work together.
Duval is wonderful as the troubled Michel, holding the interest even as it becomes clear there is more smoke here than fire.

Those who can't buy in to the long takes, frequently static camerawork and repetetive style, will struggle to stay fidget-free. Yet, if you are willing to fall into Tarr's deliberate rhythm, there is a beauty to his story.
McDonagh takes what could be a hackneyed tale of mismatched buddy cops and spins it to blisteringly funny effect.
A gripping and emotionally affecting consideration of the casual evils that men do.
While Sartet's back story is as pulpy as they come, it's the delivery that matters and in terms of action thrills, Cavayé never takes his foot off the throttle.
Squarely aimed at a student demographic, the entire affair plays out like an episode of Scooby Doo on acid with the added fuel of frequent sex.
Leaves you with the sense of a good film that has been lost somewhere along the line.
In a filmic landscape littered with the lurching corpses of zombies and the emotional angst of vampires, it's refreshing to be presented with a mythology that is less familiar.
Worthington is so wooden it's a wonder rubbing up against Mendes doesn't cause him to spontaneously combust.
While this film may run out of steam, Shackleton's bravery and that of his crew didn't and this is an undeniably fitting testimony.

movie_review_blurb: Pertinent without being overtly political, Pushing The Elephant moves along the documentary story of the Congo, one which we can all only hope will ultimately have a happy ending.

Ali Samadi Ahadi paints a poetic and heartfelt portrait of a nation oppressed.
This is not a film seeking resolution, but a snapshot of life, inviting scrutiny.

Just a whisker away from being the cat's whiskers.

Layer in the realisation that what you are seeing actually happened and the result takes you beyond disturbing into that place where your skin starts to creep and your brain crawls into the foetal position.
Deserves to find a place in the hearts of wistful romantics everywhere, no matter what their sexual preference.
Jes Benstock's documentary is a big glittery hug of a celebration.
movie_title: The British Guide To Showing Off (2011)

movie_review_blurb: Vibrant, vulgar and pretty damn funny.

movie_review_blurb: If you are willing to accept that this is an exploratory snapshot that seeks to confine itself to the times it is portraying and leave any consideration of modern-day echoes to the conscience of the viewer, this is a good story, well told.

Its structure aims for Shakespeare, but is little more than shaky, its dialogue is dire and there is enough ham and wood in the performances to make a perfectly good barbecue.

The microcosm of the children's world is exceptionally well drawn.
The "love" on offer in this romcom that marks yet another notch of disappointment on Steve Carrell's career is neither crazy nor stupid, just cynical and schmaltzy by turns
Big on atmosphere but light on plot.
Like a sort of laughter thong, it covers very little and doesn't save the blushes of anyone involved.

This isn't the breed of spying popularised by James Bond, full of glamour and girls, this is the brass tacks end of the market, where commitment to country comes with a sheaf of paper and a public school briefcase.
Frothy, funny and utterly charming.

Harmless enough to a point... but the idea that girls should aspire to little more than acquiring a boyfriend, a home or a brand-new pair of Blahniks will be desperately depressing for any parents dragged along.

Though it is perfectly watchable, it latches onto the more simplistic domestic aspect of the story at the expense of exploring the more difficult and complex political issues that enable this sort of killing to come about in the first place.
The cast are clearly having such an immense amount of fun you really can't help but join them.

Featuring plenty of visceral thrills and presented with more intelligence than many of the thrillers which spring from Hollywood strafing cliche bullets to little effect, it suggests everyone concerned is destined for bigger, better things in the future.

Bonke and Keofoed have crafted a compelling portrait that asks questions about the nature and inherent dangers of competition, ambition, sacrifice and commitment both on and off the dance floor.
An observational and utterly uncompromising document of the lives of two children touched by war.
movie_title: Domani torno a casa (Back Home Tomorrow) (2008)

movie_review_blurb: The more I thought about the cuddly critter after I'd watched this funny and heart warming short, the more I liked him.
This is an ambitious and brave project which, if it doesn't quite reach the heights it might, is still a worthwhile watch and bodes well for both filmmakers in future.
This is a fiercely intellectual piece of cinema that still manages to grab your heart and punch you in the gut.
Like its central character, this is beautiful and brave even if it fails to fully realise its potential.

Those who remember the tragic events 76 years ago are fantastic characters, open and honest in their opinions and allowed to be themselves without the guiding voice of an interviewer. This intimacy makes for a fascinating and compelling film.

If you're prepared to go with the vibe of quiet menace mixed with bone dry humour and a sense of melancholy that pervades, you will find as much pleasure in the texture of this film as the overall look.
A melancholy and, in places, excruciatingly slow take on the tale with virtually all the comedic moments pared away.
As gruelling as it is compelling.
If you like epic romances such as Dr Zhivago, this provides a decent story of will they/won't they love, although its all rather U certificate.
The young cast has a natural air that complements the unforced scripting, which brims with an enviable amount of casual humour.
The subject of understanding and mystery prove a sticking point, with the film remaining so wilfully opaque that it is more frustrating than rewarding by the end credits.

Director Juan Antonio Bayona spins the focus in on a single family caught up in the disaster, personalising the horror and bringing it home in unashamedly melodramatic fashion on its very own tidal wave of emotion.
Offering a British twist on the mumblecore genre, writer/director Alex Barrett's debut feature doesn't lack bravery.
Like the baseball diamond that features so prominently in his film, we all know which base will be dutifully tapped next and that a home-run for the characters is inevitable.
While Camping isn't breaking any new ground, it ploughs the old furrows with finesse - steering clear of Carry On crassness - and never takes itself too seriously.
This is a masterclass in tension and character exploration.
This Caterpillar creeps under your skin and stays there.
Always a cat's whisker away from cliché.
This Epic is unlikely to go down in family animation legend but it's a perfectly respectable couple of hours of entertainment that is suitable for all ages.
The saving grace of the scripting silliness is a good dollop of humour, proving that writer Chris Morgan is fully aware of its daftness.
Baz Luhrmann and co-writer Craig Pearce take the slow, slow, quick, quick, slow rhythms of the foxtrot to heart in this adaptation of F Scott Fitzgerald's The Great Gatsby.
By setting the action within a quasi-mythic framework Nichols is able to draw us into his big adventure and help us to rediscover the whispers of youth.

While in some ways the collapsing of the Siegels' wealth may seem like commeuppance for their excessiveness, Greenfield has painted such a human portrait that Jackie, in particular, remains sympathetic, even when she is adding to her own tragedy.
Wrathall's considered, thorough and thoroughly entertaining film gives not just a sense of the man but also the importance to the world of iconoclasts like him.
movie_title: Gore Vidal: The United States Of Amnesia (2014)

movie_review_blurb: Like the monster evoked by the film's title, everything feels tacked together.

Like the advent calendar Rene gives to Michi to count down the days to Christmas, the film holds a surprising number of sweet treats, despite its austere veneer.
This is an impressionistic portrait, as multi-faceted and delicate as the flies which we see being created at points through the film.
When it comes to what ultimately drove these two men to kill, Porto and Moors are more interested in difficult questions than easy answers and their film hits its target hard.
Fontaine is a capable director...But the moment that the dialogue begins, any nuance is lost, with key emotional moments generating laughter rather than empathy.

Films like this are important because they reveal the real faces behind the barrage of news statistics. Faces belonging to people who have as much of a right to live out their lives in peace without fear as we do.
movie_title: Mit Afghanistan: Livet i den forbudte zone (My Afghanistan: Life in the Forbidden Zone) (2012)

movie_review_blurb: The pace - and subtitling - may be frantic and the comedy occasionally too broad, but there is also subtle satire underpinning the surface.

Financial crime can be difficult to follow and dull to relate ... But Nicholas Jarecki keeps the paper stuff straightforward and the action interesting by bolting it on to a more conventional thriller plot.

The reference to the push-me, pull-you state of adolescence - with twin forces drawing you back towards childhood and on into adulthood - is the most interesting idea in the movie but it is otherwise swamped by cliche.

This series is, by turns, moving and hilarious, poignant and frivolous.
At the film's heart lies the paradox: how can a con artist be conning people if he is freely admitting that is what he is doing?

Andrew Norriss and Richard Fegen give their characters a real sense of warmth.
Freeland captures the beauty of Tanzania and uses the landscape as a way of illustrating the isolation and loneliness suffered by those with albinism.
movie_title: In The Shadow Of The Sun (2012)

movie_title: La maison sous les arbres (The Deadly Trap) (1971)

movie_review_blurb: Built on the shifting sands of childhood and adolescence, She Monkeys has an undercurrent of unease in which the characters are struggling to become 'adult', whatever that may mean.

It is Dunham's fearlessness in showing Aura warts and all that becomes endearing.
Shenk gets almost unfettered acccess to Nasheed, who is refreshingly honest about the tactics he is employing to get other countries onside

The film's heart is certainly in the right place, but its narrative is more of a scattergun affair.
The only thing Martens takes seriously is his humour - and it pays off handsomely.
Succeeds on an emotional level even if it fails to deliver anything very surprising in terms of plot.

A thought-provoking consideration of ageing from the perspective of the elderly that is, perhaps ironically, hard to forget.

A humanist hug of a fable, which concludes that while big miracles may happen, it's the everyday 'miracles' people create for one another that really count.

Bolstered by the great and the good of homegrown acting royalty, it just about gets away with the fact that Ol Parker's screenplay... at times pushes the humour parlously close to Carry On Up The Elderly.

Subversive and incendiary.

While Brave may occasionally shy away from darker territory in order to retain its appeal for even the youngest of audiences, there are still plenty of 'big' ideas here for small minds to think about.

Always charmingly frothy, even when the narrative threatens to salsa off with the fairies.

It isn't a film with a lot of big guffaws, but I smiled through most of it.
It all amounts to a certain brand of comedy -- something closer to long-form Dada than conventional humor.
Half the time I wanted everyone to shut up so I could hear the tour guide lecture on the Temple of Hephaestus, or wherever. Then I wanted them to shut up so I could sleep.
Is it as hilarious as the Evil Deads? Almost.
Even if you don't quite comprehend the ending (there seem to be 12 of them), you'll still feel the wallop of its consequences.
The film offers enough ingenious touches and playful humor that the less-inspired elements hit with a screech.

Hypnotic and ultimately incomplete.

It is a sumptuous visual feast and a perfectly enchanting story.

The sharpest Hollywood satire since The Player.

An uneven but sweet-natured bop through the unstable ground of teenage lust and loneliness.

Slumdog Millionaire is not the cure for all the world's ills, but it comes close. It solves, for instance, such endemic global problems as: a) sadness, b) lovelessness, c) cynicism, and d) the waning cultural relevance of Who Wants to Be a Millionaire.
Somehow, Milk implants hope in those who've lost it. Somehow, Penn plays him as a feisty charmer so winning and lifelike that you'll regard him as a friend before it's over.
Comedy and tragedy, action and melodrama, full measures of quirk and swoon: It's just a plain good time at the movies.
Thomas gives it her all, uncorking every ounce of emotion she'd held in check, with Herculean restraint, over the better part of two hours.

Gothic wooziness stifles many of Hardwicke's lighter impulses, such as her knack for jiving humor in scenes among friends and family. And some of the more cartoonishly gymnastic CG stunts look plain silly.

Director David Fincher has turned out an overlong, Forrest Gumpian exercise in mannered whimsy. It's sentimental; it's episodic; it dawdles. Brad Pitt spends a good length of screen time drinking tea with Tilda Swinton. But it's also bewitching.
movie_title: The Curious Case of Benjamin Button (2008)

[A] noisy, eccentric, bizarrely lovable film.

An alluring piece of work, an artful whodunit that melds shrewd plotting with resourceful camera work and sympathetic characters that are fascinatingly, morbidly off.

Exploits every cliché with abundant good cheer and an admirable, unapologetic ridiculousness.

A subtle work on an exceedingly difficult subject.

movie_review_blurb: [Ramona] deserves better treatment, fairer justice, than she gets in Ramona and Beezus, for no other reason than she's the best thing in it: a rambunctious, bright-eyed mighty mouse with a kaleidoscopic wardrobe and an imagination to match.
What a crock.

movie_review_blurb: Director Chris Columbus has brought together the modern and mythical spheres with sharp pacing and a nifty sense of fun that atone for the film's dippier moments. It's his most enjoyable effort since Harry Potter and the Chamber of Secrets.
movie_title: Percy Jackson & the Olympians: The Lightning Thief (2010)

movie_review_blurb: None of this is scary, and nothing makes sense.

The dogs are cute -- I'll say that for it.

Awesome. Truly.

Sure, it's complicated, but isn't that always true of romance? And doesn't it blow the hinges off the universe -- every single time?
It takes an iron stomach to watch this stuff and not feel nauseated.

Zemeckis' film preserves much of Dickens' original dialogue and detail while amplifying the utter ethereal strangeness of the ghosts.

Writer-director Meyers, who's devoted much of her career to midlife American arousal, that she loses her sense of fun.

The most-hyped movie of the year just about merits it.
Every now and then, a film comes along that both defies and compels description.

Beyond question, the results are overstated, outrageous and wildly, scatologically juvenile. But they're also a hoot to watch.
movie_title: The Yes Men Fix the World (2009)

movie_review_blurb: Anderson injects such charm and wit, such personality and nostalgia -- evident in the old-school animation, storybook settings and pitch-perfect use of Burl Ives -- that it's easy to forgive his self-conscious touches.
My, but it's been a fine year for Armageddon.

The movie as a whole isn't exactly ground-breaking, and some of the humor tanks. But it has enough action, laughs and candy-hued visuals to satisfy the target audience without plunging grown-ups into despair.

What a triumph of a film.
movie_title: Precious: Based on the Novel Push by Sapphire (2009)

movie_review_blurb: It's nice to know that the studio behind Cinderella can still cast a spell in two dimensions.

A poignant and expertly restrained meditation on greed and financial hardship in rural Spain.
A much needed but underwhelming ode to pacifism and the futility of war.
Clunky and affected, with too little drama to carry the narrative.
Some decent gags, but the film quickly falls to pieces despite Johnson's best efforts.
A thoughtful meditation on female agency in contemporary Tehran.
Benjamin Bratt, the pretty boy once seen on the arm of America's sweetheart Julia Roberts, plays Piñero with a passion. It's a star-making performance.
The film lacks visual ingenuity, but the point isn't to show us something new - it's to tell us something we might not have heard. And what Chomsky says is as unsettling as it is persuasive.
Beltracchi: The Art of Forgery makes us question not only art, but the experts who claim to understand it best.
At times the comic tone undercuts the hunters' pleas to be taken seriously. But mostly it raises the question of how seriously the filmmakers take poaching.
In A Ballerina's Tale, director Nelson George paints a moving portrait of Copeland that underscores her triumphs over bodily and historical limitations.
The filmmakers, like the songbirds they advocate for, are only messengers, but their message is persuasive and terrifying.
The film is most persuasive when demonstrating that the need for solar energy transcends partisan politics.

After speaking to several environmental experts, hiking for hours through the Amazon, and discovering just how momentous the threat of climate change is to humanity as we know it, documentarian Josh Fox made a film about himself.
movie_title: How to Let Go of the World and Love All the Things Climate Can't Change (2016)

movie_review_blurb: Emptying the Skies performs a grand and aching love by telling its story with a power that enrages.
The film offers fascinating insight into what yarn can do in the talented hands of those determined to elevate mere craft to high art.
This doc is a tearjerker, but it's also enraging. Taken together, these stories add up to a larger and deeply troubling narrative about what it's like to be a woman living in America today.
Adam tells his father's story with love, but he resists hagiography.
Frustrating but frequently compelling ...
Meditative in its slowness and exquisite beauty, Portrait of a Garden is more than a fine documentary - it's a balm for the soul.
movie_title: Portrait of a Garden (Portret van een tuin) (2016)

movie_review_blurb: The film is saved by its illuminating - if heartbreaking - examination of isolated locales rarely seen on film.
The film relies solely on patient testimony to argue for the legalization of the injections. But what it lacks in comprehensive research, it makes up for in fascinating rhetoric.
Roger Spottiswoode's slight but warmhearted A Street Cat Named Bob ekes uplift out of melodrama.
Begin Again is essentially the bubble gum pop version of Inside Llewyn Davis.
This is a movie a girl could see with her mom and a big ol' pretzel on a rainy day.

The narrative is dense, but understandably so, and not without its light moments. A richly informative investigation, it pulls viewers along on a political and legal thrill ride that will have you cheering the central couples on scene after scene.
The best thing I can say about the violent indie horror/thriller You're Next is that it had a kick-ass heroine and some creepy animal masks.
Margaret is a pointless coming-of-age drama starring Anna Paquin that tediously meanders on for two and half hours before ending with a whimper.
Retreat sports some high-caliber actors in a claustrophobic home-invasion thriller a la Straw Dog that offers up some truly thrilling moments.
Dolphin Tale, an inspirational tale about a Little Dolphin Who Could, will swim into your heart despite some melodrama and predictability.
The gratuitous and exploitative nature of the violence, coupled with very little story development and plot, makes for a film without any real purpose other to shock and appall.
Guillermo del Toro's Don't Be Afraid of the Dark is as murky and ill-conceived as its multitude of dimly-lit corners,
movie_title: Don't Be Afraid Of The Dark (2011)

movie_review_blurb: Real Steel envisions a future where boxing has evolved into giant fighting robots. Great special effects and cool fight choreography makes this a must-see.
Fright Night is an easily digested horror that doesn't rise above being just decent.
Snow Flower and the Secret Fan is a delicate, if sometimes disturbing, portrait of the enduring relationships that bond women together, out in theaters now.
movie_title: Snow Flower And The Secret Fan (2011)

movie_review_blurb: Winnie the Pooh is a charming addition to the Pooh collection of animated family films.
The Ward might not bode too well for Carpenter's come back, but he did do good things with what he had to work with (clichéd story and script).
Great action sequences and a touching story make Super 8 a great summer blockbuster.
Larry Crowne is nothing we haven't seen before and at times feels over-done and cliched.
Kevin James' new comedy Zookeeper may be popular with the kiddos, but slapstick humor and a cookie-cutter storyline doom it for adults.
The Smurfs is a cute family film that suffers from being a little formulaic and uninspired, and the CGI smurfs don't look like the original characters.
Emilio Estevez hasn't just been making wine lately. His film The Way, an inspirational drama, is a thoughtful travel pic worth seeing.
Roland Emmerich takes a questionable literary controversy and deftly forms it into an Elizabethan political drama in the Shakespeare-themed 'Anonymous'.
Coriolanus is Shakespeare done right; Ralph Fiennes takes a play about Roman war and hubris and turns it into a violently charismatic pic.
Despite the excellently creepy subject matter, The Tall Man contains very little actual horror and ends up being quite a dud.
Overall, this is one comedy I hope never makes it to theaters. Ok, it's a step or two above Bucky Larson, but it's not worth the price of admission.
21 Jump Street takes the basic concept of the original series, and uses it to create an action/comedy that is not only palatable to modern audiences, but appealing as well.
What I can definitely tell you, without giving away any of its secrets, is that Cabin In The Woods is going to be a pleasant surprise for just about everyone.
Like Crazy manages to capture the elusive whimsy of first love, only to beat it to death with a tedious on again/off again love story and two main characters obstinately selfish and mundane.
The consistently negative study of Hoover, along with pell-mell story telling and a melodramatic and silly gay romance, make J. Edgar a disappointing film.
Moneyball is more interesting than your typical sports drama thanks to the direction. Bennett Miller takes a rather grey, cement-enshrouded setting and gives it a little pizzazz.
Ok, so V/H/S/ has its drawbacks, but for such a collaborative directorial effort I think it worked pretty well.

The muppets are back, just like we remember them, with catchy tunes and meta humor. Also, a great cast of cameo appearances is paired with a fun story and iconic characters that haven't been detrimentally modernized.
30 Minutes Or Less has enough of both action and comedy to appeal to multiple demographics, and as far as crude comedies go it's a fun watch.
This "cabin-in-the-woods" horror pic gets off to a good start with subtle chills and a fresh concept, but ultimately suffers from a weak, overly vague ending.
The Hunter delivers a quiet and somewhat meandering story that wallows in self-importance and social agenda.
Happy Feet Two is a fun uplifting family flick that accomplishes exactly what it sets out to do.
For those still in possession of their wits, this film is not only the worst of the Twilight flicks so far, but just about the most melodramatic and insipid movie I've ever watched.
I'm not sure how many tedious sex jokes and humorless physical gags people can take before they run out of the theater screaming, but Bucky Larson: Born to Be a Star certainly tests the limits.
movie_title: Bucky Larson: Born to Be a Star (2011)

movie_review_blurb: Evil Dead lacks the humor and sub-genre-launching power of the original, but it's a solid remake that is definitely worth watching, even and especially if you are a fan of the original.
The Incredible Burt Wonderstone is by no means an awful film, and it does have some genuinely funny moments, it just offers nothing new and comes off as stale and recycled for the most part.
Outstanding performances and a delicate approach to racial tensions make this film a cut above other inspirational period dramas.
Drinking Buddies wasn't the worst I've seen from Swanberg (luckily no meandering-film-student feel to this one), but it wasn't very compelling or interesting either.
Jodie Foster's The Beaver had its moments, but the overall premise just didn't fly. I just couldn't buy the idea of the talking puppet.
Beginners, beyond its pervasive atmosphere of melancholy and loss, suffers from a little self-indulgence. It's your typical indie drama.
The film presents interesting historical information with a great Christmas-y soundtrack, making for a somewhat enjoyable watch.
Hobo With A Shotgun is a film in the tradition of 70s exploitation films. But unlike most grindhouse films, this one is actually awesome.
Mars Needs Moms actually entertained me. There's the bright colors and great 3D, but there's also some touching moments and grown-up wit
So this isn't a great re-imagining of the classic fairy tale Beauty and the Beast, but Beastly does have mass tweener appeal.
Before Midnight is one of those dialogue-driven indie dramas that make you appreciate the medium of film.
Insidious is effectively creepy and is able to provide some great horror elements without the gore.
The killer tire concept is great and the bizarre humor works very well, making this a wholly enjoyable film.
Though geared towards a young adult audience, I Am Number Four entertains with sleek special effects, scary aliens, and superhero action.

Despite its bleak atmosphere and sparse storyline, period drama The Eagle is a pleasant surprise. It entertains with some great sword play, and the themes of honor and bravery overcome the simplicity of the story.
Sophomoric humor and a lack of substance make Gnomeo and Juliet a rather forgettable flick.
Poor character development, a thin plot and predictability make this one a forgettable film.
The Way Back is an inspiring story that is beautifully photographed and full of interesting and well acted characters.
An enjoyable low-budget horror flick, Vanishing on 7th Street has all the thrills and chills you could hope for from a film like this.
A thoughtful study of relationships and family dynamics, Win Win wrestles the competition to the ground.
A sort of comedy homage to seminal sci-fi movie culture from the 80s, Paul never takes itself too seriously and is a lot of fun.
The amateurish animation and excessive vulgarity is a turn off, and the light-weight plot/storyline doesn't help matters either.
Great dark humor and enjoyable performances make this one a winner. Surprisingly, the animated sequences also work quite well.
A surreal experience that will no doubt polarize, The Lords of Salem feels more like a bad LSD trip than a cohesive horror movie.
A mundane and tired story that lacks depth doesn't exactly make Skateland an exciting or even enjoyable film.

The lack of story or purpose is annoying and at times, the film is too experimental. Topping things off is an abrupt and unsatisfying ending which doesn't leave us with good feelings towards the film.
Much Ado About Nothing is a cute and stylish modern adaptation of Shakespeare's play, but it's largely unremarkable especially when compared to film versions that are already out there.
Dylan Dog: Dead Of Night is a fun comedy/horror whodunnit with a supernatural twist. It delivers plenty of movie fun too, just like those campy 80's monster flicks.
Great fight scenes and diverse martial arts make for a very entertaining film.
Wholesome story, colorful characters and sweet romantic elements, make for a decent watch.
The leads lack chemistry and the movie has a very cookie-cutter love story that was far too predictable.
A miscast Russell Brand and some poor writing make the film nothing but a decent one time watch.
While staying true to Rand's vision, Atlas Shrugged: Part 1 suffers from poor directing and it lacks the sleekness it needs to connect with audiences.
Weak plot, half-assed performances and lacking any originality make this a lame and uninspired film.
Cold Sweat is a nonsensical horror film out of Argentina. With a plot so illogical it's hard to describe, it didn't work on any level.
Fantastic pacing, an excellent performance by Gyllenhaal and smart storytelling make this a wonderful film.
A rather anemic version of Charlotte Bronte's classic novel, Focus Film and BBC's Jane Eyre favors atmosphere over strong narrative.
Trite dialogue, poor special effects and an insubstantial storyline make this one a bit of a dud.
An unlikeable main character and a weak narrative flow turn Hesher into a mediocre film.
An enjoyably written and performed romantic comedy.
Bigger, sleeker and better than the first, sequel Charlie's Angels: Full Throttle is a joyride of a movie that takes the winning elements of the year 2000 hit to the next level.

movie_review_blurb: This is a film that so respects love -- if it exists -- that it won't settle for imitations.
"After all these years, I just sort of go with it," shrugs Harry Potter. Six films in, so do we.
movie_title: Harry Potter and the Half-Blood Prince (2009)

If watching this makes you long to be young again, you probably grew up in an Algerian prison.

This worthy second biopic of Truman Capote starts not with a bloodbath, but a cocktail.

Despite the audacious title and premise, Range doesn't aim to shock, but to unnerve
Noyce is now the favorite filmmaker of your local Amnesty International
They expected tension; what they didn't expect was to serve out their year-long deployment as, essentially, the world's most targeted grocery store security.

Not just dumb, it's dopey, moronic, doltish, obtuse and thick.
A little morally perverse under the surface, as Bateman learns that one of the keys to happiness is an attitude of "Let them eat cherry-flavored cake."

It's harsh, but it's sweetened by Toby -- he's not a real boy, but he's a classic hero.
Swank has fun in the role - I haven't seen her smile this much in years - but she isn't given much complicated to do besides frustrate her friends when she digs in her heels.

If there's a night at the movies more fun than this deadpan blaxploitation flick, it's probably boosted by something bought in a dark alley.

A film Barack Obama would approve of screening for Sasha and Malia -- there's even a jab at private health insurers.
One of the best girl casts of the year. You don't leave wanting to pick up the DVD, but you do want to pick up a set of dumbbells.

I think I speak for all adults and kids when I say I can't wait for playtime

Lord and Miller know how to play with their food -- they have a hunger for the whimsical detail

movie_review_blurb: A satire made for cult rediscovery, just change the tagline to "In the foam, no one can hear you scream."

movie_review_blurb: I've got no problem with movies that stack up twists like crazy straws. Hyam's script, however, depends on us being dumber than every character in the film-you'd have to reach protozoan levels just to resist wanting to strangle everyone in it.
It'd be nice (and fair) if Cutler dared ask Wintour about her reasons rather than framing her march to the layout room as though she's a Chanel-suited Darth Vader.
The worst thing you can say about 9 is that it's the look, not the script, that keeps your interest.

A screenplay that feels written by numbers, but excellent performances make it deserve more attention than this late summer dump
Honesty defines the performances. The happiest possible ending here and in real life is that people keep going forward no matter how hard it hurts.

movie_review_blurb: Approached as comedy, Cover is a riot.

The coast of Australia is an apt setting for Rod Hardy's precious drama: It's Beaches for men.

movie_review_blurb: Penn's main idea about going native is making eye contact with a deer.

movie_review_blurb: A fascinating exploration of art, creativity, and family dynamics that takes an unexpected right hook.

A pedigreed romance, an excuse for Blanchett to bind herself in satin and channel Kate Hepburn.

A precocious fairy tale made for and starring people too old for whimsy

After the 14th song, casual fans feel guilty that their energy is flagging while then-63 Mick's still huffing on

movie_review_blurb: James' outlandish ruses to make his firstborn a Wildcat are fun; the push-pull parent-child dynamic generic, but sweet. But the writers comedy failsafe is "Cut to the pig!"

Steroids as demonized innocents is a tough pill to swallow, and while Bell isn't out to build a clear case, he succeeds in muddying the waters.
time ticks by easily like a lazy TV marathon, a humbler achievement than demanded by a diva flick that's as self-congratulatory as Indy across the multiplex
Zalla wants to know the point where boys become cynics, men become vultures, and the hardened become vulnerable.
Indy isn't boning up on Babylonian texts; he's leafing through the Weekly World News.
movie_title: Indiana Jones and the Kingdom of the Crystal Skull (2008)

movie_review_blurb: Twice as violent and half as funny as anything resembling a good movie, it's still a hell of a ride
If we have to learn life lessons from a God Cat, do they have to side with Bill O'Reilly?
movie_title: The Chronicles of Narnia: Prince Caspian (2008)

movie_review_blurb: Like his subjects, Norwegian writer-director Joachim Trier is young and bursting with ambition
We're left after this terse and anxious film knowing nothing more about the world than that Janssen looks cool bending over and glaring at the eight-ball
Even bedridden, Broadbent walks away with the film; his son's never outshone him and Firth can't do much besides sulk.
movie_title: When Did You Last See Your Father? (2008)

movie_review_blurb: There are worse movies, but most restrain themselves to only one scene of Daniel Stern learning to salsa.
Their customers are awkward enough that we're able to believe the girls are in control, or at least aware that they're the highlight of the men's week.
Sliding from past to present without an overt purpose, Jakob's story has the grand and aimless sweep of a mini-series
Harmony Korine's films thrive on uncertain ground. Exiting the theater, you're never more aware that ten people can sit next to each other but see ten different films.
David Mamet must have gotten roundhouse kicked in the head to think there was a story worth telling in his latest macho faceoff.
Jeff Nichols modern Western is laconic and lazily captivating, its silence slowly building to rage.
What's epic in Morris' still and haunting assembly of talking heads is an indictment of photography, and by extension, history.

Baby Mama is hilarious. I could quote its awesome one-liners out of context for diminishing returns. It's also smart. The jokes are cribbed from the anxiety list of anyone who's spent too much time reading the New York Times Style section.
What this film knows about grief, you could put in a haiku. (It'd read: "Death sucks, like really/Nothing else matters, ever/Therapy-what's that?")
The whole film feels like Apatow and clan are still on their own vacation after last summer's one-two punch.
The chicks may be topless, but this horror schlock wears its pretensions on its sleeve.
Steve Conrad's wry debut takes place in an urban Chicago grocery store, in which an intimate epic of manhood unfolds.
Zohan's a shallow character even by Sandler's standards, a bunch of crotch thrusts in search of a laugh.
movie_title: You Don't Mess With the Zohan (2008)

movie_review_blurb: Lacking great themes and inner depth, Mongol is just another galloping wondershow of ice blue skies and rocky plains, a light diversion with delusions of grandeur
The film is lightest on its feet when it shakes off the Red Shoe Diaries foreboding for moments of sly irony
This melodrama about capital punishment has no shades of gray, only beige.
Our appetite for watching young people do silly, overly sincere, and sometimes brave things has been slaked by the glut of junk-food TV shows on the subject.
Ferrell is the third best teenage boy I've ever seen but John C. Reilly may be the greatest comic actor of our generation -- he's fearlessly earnest and incapable of mugging.
The only way to enjoy Kari Skogland's epic portrait of a miserable 90-year- woman named Hagar (Ellen Burstyn) is to reframe it as Scary Movie for weepies.
This banana-brained picture doesn't deliver. Parents will prefer shuttling everyone to a second showing of WALL-E.
I'm betraying my childhood to concede this, but Nolan has finally topped Tim Burton's two twisted spectaculars.
Director Gilliam Anderson doesn't distinguish this generic romance from a thousand other costumed bodice rippers -- is a kinky handcuff scene too much to ask?
Oddly, halfway through when Freeland strains our credulity even further, the film finally feels fresh
Director Eric Brevig knows he's not really shooting a Jules Verne mind-blower; this is pure blockbuster, and it's a fine specimen.
movie_title: Journey to the Center of the Earth (2008)

movie_review_blurb: Del Toro creates great machines, but besides the fluke of the first Hellboy, his characters leave me cold.
Amusing, but shallow-audiences who trickle in expecting more than a romp will find it's too innocuous to stir up any post-film debates.
A slog through determined wackiness, it's apt to leave audiences cold.
Like Running with Scissors or an exceptionally cruel episode of The Wonder Years, Paul Weiland's whimsical and eye-poppingly bright comedy is shot through with cringe-inducing misery.
The dynamic between the sullen Smith and sincere Bateman may be the best thing in the Peter Berg's movie, but it's a tough call because the whole popcorn fest is flat-out fantastic.
It's hard to dislike a tween picture that opens with Eleanor Roosevelt, but if explaining mortgage meltdowns to their tots doesn't sent parents screaming, the performances will.
Alex Gibney's documentary can't decide if it's a eulogy for fans or a primer for acquaintances.
movie_title: Gonzo: The Life and Work of Hunter S. Thompson (2008)

movie_review_blurb: A beautiful film that makes us proud of the species that created it, even as we root for the robot who inadvertently saves us from ourselves
The best way to learn about Trumbo is through his writing, which is spirited, dry, and utterly convinced of its truth
Postures as empathetic while getting its leading lady out of her skivvies -- there's nothing bold about taking a stance against human trafficking
Made of 50 short, stiff scenes of human behavior, shot as dispassionately as wildlife, Andersson is either stretching the definition of cinema or returning it to its roots
The familiar premise here has sharp fangs, unsparing wit and a knockout performance by Brittany Snow as the round-heeled 20-year-old.
This mystical, cynical, hypocritical elegy is his return to the deep after his somnolent The Wild Blue Yonder, and like it, plunges into the unique territory of Herzog's mind
movie_title: Encounters at the End of the World (2007)

movie_review_blurb: Steve Carell is still searching for the knockout role that fits, but Smart's suits come yards closer than Bruce's almighty robes.
Mike Myers' catastrophe is a paramount test of enlightenment. Smiling beatifically during each painfully unfunny gag demands more inner-strength than jogging through lava.
When the Hulk turns back, he often finds himself naked, aching, and disoriented in Guatemala, the fate of many a Spring Breaker
While the Baekelands would be flattered to rank with Clytemnestra and Oedipus, they and the film are as shallow as martinis
Though he has a shorthand approach to capturing 1994, Levine nails the swirling energy of first heartbreak as his teen stoner rehearses his first Big Moment
You walk away wishing the filmmaker had channeled the guts he showed in crossing dangerous borders with his subjects into asking them tough and insightful questions
There's the core of a fascinating amoral movie here before it gets amped up into a standard thriller
The brink of annihilation looks like a low-budget music video.
Like the Puritans themselves, the movie shuns drama. It has too much moral virtue for jump scares.
This concept of single still assumes that a woman must have a man, that a girl's only choice is between one boyfriend or 20.
In the dailies of Hail, Caesar!'s fictional Hail, Caesar!, a title card reads, "Divine presence to be shot." To the Coens, is that a promise or a threat?
A wholly fictitious bus blast had my audience applauding with glee. "That was for us!" a character grins. Yes, literally - it was invented for a crowd that prefers fist-pumping to facts.
movie_title: 13 Hours: The Secret Soldiers Of Benghazi (2016)

movie_review_blurb: A wry salute to the world's hard-drinking, eye-rolling aid workers, men and women whose high ideals get crushed by global bureaucracy and local recalcitrance.
I wanted more time with almost all of the subplots - I got invested in their small, relatable agonies - which is both a complaint and a compliment.
The Force Awakens steers the franchise back to its popcorn origins. It's not a Bible; it's a bantamweight blast. And that's just as it should be: a good movie, nothing more.
movie_title: Star Wars: Episode VII - The Force Awakens (2015)

movie_review_blurb: What's quietly revolutionary about Sisters is that it's a dumb-party movie like a million others.
Moby-Dick was a story of fever and obsession. Ron Howard is interested in something more cynically modern: corporate greed.
movie_title: In the Heart of the Sea (2015)

movie_review_blurb: Chi-Raq is a marvel. It's Lee resurrecting his voice - angry, impassioned and funny as hell - right when we need to hear it.
The great mystery of the script: Why does The Danish Girl pretend to cheer Lili's courage while changing the facts to make her seem selfish?
Stallone can't let go of the spotlight, even though he barely has a handle on his own character. His Balboa has been Xeroxed too many times; he's all blurry around the edges.
In the first Hunger Games film, we were simply meant to care whether Katniss won. Three movies later, the series has become about how horrible it can be to win.
It hurts to see those bars erected around the house. It hurts worse to see them mounted in the girls' minds.
"Jesus," Jolie groans, "have I become that dull?" Yes, in fact, and with her name all over the credits, there's no one else to blame.
To sit through it feels like honoring the dreamers of the world who at least get shit done. Is it terrible? Of course. Is there belly-dancing? Duh.
A music box trying to pass itself off as an orchestra.
A horror film wrapped in a fast-talking political comedy.
The nearly two-hour run time starts to feel like a concert where the hype men won't get off the stage.
Nasty Baby takes aim at a fat target: gay modern-family dramedies, those well-meaning, self-congratulatory films that haven't actually felt modern in a decade.
Bridge of Spies connects Cold War paranoia to today's terror. That's a bridge worth building.
A faithful homage to a foolish genre. The risk is that audiences who don't share that love won't appreciate the work, like the world's best cover band nailing obscure nu-metal hits
Abrahamson is fascinated by happiness and hope: how Jack can see joy in this dungeon, and how Joy can dream of freedom when her son can't comprehend that there's anywhere else to go.
This sparse marvel leaves the audience rattled by how small decisions lead to big consequences.
Finders Keepers sees the tragedy in Whisnant's egomania. As he agrees to a tacky reality show, we realize he's peddling something more valuable than a leg - he's selling his soul.
It's pointed about how we treat today's zealots, as when Clavius likens the pain of crucification to "sucking air through a wet cloth" - a description of waterboarding.
#AllLivesMatter? Not here. Hillcoat wants us to admit the truth behind the robbers' callous calculation: Some people are worth more than others.
It's tempting to dismiss Gods of Egypt as the most perfectly bad film I've ever seen. But that's not fair. It's perfectly itself - a bizarre, yet cohesive, construction.
A girl-power comedy with a bold twist: The timid heroine blossoms in Afghanistan, one of the most female-unfriendly countries on earth.
When I saw Tickled at Sundance this January, I thought it was a fun trifle. In the months since, it's felt like a warning sign of the mediapocalypse.
Morbidity covers every scale of Finding Dory like fin rot.
Wan can't resist throwing in everything from a demonic nun to an evil kinetoscope to a shape-shifting dog. But when building suspense, more means less.
Duncan Jones puts in strange, fresh beats that, combined, do the impossible. They make this standard, shopworn, CG-plated epic feel like its own monster.
It's So Easy plays like a public Alcoholics Anonymous meeting with McKagan at the mic apologizing for his misdeeds.
movie_title: It's So Easy and Other Lies (2016)

movie_review_blurb: Consider it the Decathlon of Dude Bros

If Bernie Sanders is elected president, Money Monster will be the only movie allowed on Air Force One.
A cynical sci-fi comedy about life's most clichéd script: pair off or perish. That's been the formula since the first primeval fish, and every living thing since has been a sequel.
Finders Keepers sees the tragedy in Whisnant's egomania. As he agrees to a tacky reality show, we realize he's peddling something more valuable than a leg - he's selling his soul.
Captain America: Civil War is a comic book pulped into today's newspaper.

Clearly, the economy has given Get a Job a reason to be sour. But there's no excuse for being so sexist.
Pee-wee doesn't come saddled with backstory, like Batman. He's more like Mickey Mouse, an icon who can become anything he wants.

Great publicity, dumb move. The title alone is a spoiler.
Grimsby's balls - actual balls - broke my dignity.

If men-children like Jake don't outgrow telling their stories, their crib will feel like an artistic prison.
Michael Douglas seems to have been slithering toward this part for 40 years

No one involved in the making of Insurgent would test positive for the intelligent Erudites

movie_review_blurb: It's fun and raw and dumb - perfect late-summer cinema. Yet Efron, one of our best young actors, gives the movie more than it needs: if not quite gravitas, an emotional tempo.

movie_review_blurb: Zagar stops just short of arguing for Smart's innocence, but he pokes enough holes in our perception of the facts.
A bloody valentine attached to a bomb. It's violent, brash, inventive and horrific, and perhaps the most romantic film of the year.
Like Brooke's dream business, a café/convenience store/hair salon, Mistress America is a mishmash of ideas

A topless, sticky-wet movie where almost no one is having sex. The boys aren't even grown up enough to say the word, preferring to ask, "Did you bangy?"

movie_review_blurb: Goodall dreamed of Africa, not domestic bliss. In one lovely shot, she stands barefoot in the rain veiled by a clear tarp wet with lacy droplets, a woman married to her ambitions.

By the time Storm King growls, "I'm so totally over the cute pony thing," misanthropes might agree. Yet, its sweetness stampedes over the audience's resistance.

The best work Jolie's done yet. Still, every time Loung's captors holler, "You must have a revolutionary spirit!", I wondered if Jolie ever feels the urge to make truly rebellious art.

Jessica Williams fills up a space like the glow of a megawatt bulb. She transitions from TV to film at light-speed, glorying in the extra room.
Each time the script wobbled into cliché, I cringed. The actresses are too talented to flail on hallucinogens. But they launch into idiocy with so much energy that even the dumbest scenes lift-off.

The play feels like stumbling upon an ancient spell.

Mute is more interesting as a bullet-point list of absurdities than as a two-hour film. Yet, Jones continues to have my attention.

A small story made with big performances from leads Stevens and Hall, and while it hasn't gotten the promotional push for audiences to pay attention, people lucky enough to stumble across it will fall for everyone involved.

movie_title: An Evening with Beverly Luff Linn (2018)
