A bit like getting relationship advice from a clown. A really, really unfunny one.
For a film that has all the inner workings of a generic sports movie, Whip It somehow avoids being one.
[Murphy] continues to treat his career like it were a game of limbo, as Imagine That sees the once gifted comedian stoop to a horrendous new low.
Essentially a collection of Family Guy cutaway gags slapped onto a DVD and played back to back. No continuing plot, no overriding characters, no particular order. Just raw, uncensored hilarity.
A bland blend of two half-baked stories. Julie & Julia spends so long celebrating the art of cooking, it forgets to be dramatic, romantic or funny.
Won't burst through the comedic stratosphere, but Stone Bros. is still a trip worth taking.
A kid-friendly caper that's drunk a bit too much CGI-spiked red cordial.
movie_title: Shorts: The Adventures of the Wishing Rock (2009)

movie_review_blurb: Moon is the kind sci-fi film you rarely see any more; subtle and intelligent. Yet it gets stuck on the launch pad to greatness.
Another near-perfect Pixarian blend of escapist fun and heart-warming sentiment.
There isn't a single word in the English language that could justly convey the sheer stupidity, and impenetrable complexity, of Push.
Despite being almost exclusively tailored to pluck at our emotional strings, The Soloist is an oddly uninvolving experience.
Driven by top-tier performances from Adams and Blunt, Sunshine Cleaning is a charming dramedy that lifts the dirt on life and death.
Packed with enough rap music, nauseating camera jerks, speed shifts and freeze frames to almost, so nearly, convince us something interesting is occurring on screen.
[Quentin Tarantino has] whacked history over the head and cut away all the boring bits, leaving behind a blood-drenched war epic like no other.
Don't believe the hype. You'll enjoy it far more that way.
Johnston's direction sidesteps suspense to deliver a surplus of tactless, out-of-nowhere jump scares that are more irritating than frightening.
Visually striking...[but] it feels as if Acker was pressured into making a money-making thrill ride instead of a mind-mulling sci-fi.
It's thrilling, chilling, amusing and moving, and if I could think of any other sensations that rhymed, The Cove would surely be those as well.
It's crude, inane and manic, but boy is it funny.
Are we really supposed to believe that an iPod's battery life will outlast religion?
The most important message of [ How to Train Your Dragon] is from DreamWorks to their rivals Pixar. It simply reads, "We're baaaack."
Do yourself a favour and avoid the 3D. Do yourself a bigger favour and avoid the film entirely
Remakes this good are one in a million.
Kick-Ass is what Spider-Man would have looked like if it was directed by Quentin Tarantino using the cast of Spy Kids. In other words, pure awesome.
Some of the jokes in [Cop Out] are so far beyond the realms of lame, you have to wonder whether it's intentional.
Even as cushy popcorn action, Green Zone misfires.
If it is to be remembered, it'll be for all the wrong reasons.
The closest you'll get to absolute madness without being locked in a room with padded walls...a wondrous piece of escapism.
Scorsese still knows how to put on one hell of a show.
Armed to the teeth with more action movie clichés than a Steven Seagal show reel. Yep, it has 'guilty pleasure' stamped all over it.
If Sendak's book spoke directly to the child inside all of us, Spike Jonze's film adaptation lets it run wild for 100 magical minutes.
Thanks to Ford's acute sense of style, such sobering themes have never looked so good.
It's likely that The Princess and the Frog will be remembered for being the first Disney animation to feature a black princess, rather than for being a great movie.
Yes, Daybreakers is another vampire film, but don't hold it against it. This is stuff Twilight fans have nightmares about...

In another time and place, Law Abiding Citizen could have been an intelligent critique of a flawed criminal justice system. Instead, I present you Gerard Butler, ruthlessly hacking a guy into 25 little pieces.
The moment Barber resorts to over-the-top violence as a means to an end, Harry Brown becomes an unintentional farce.
Up in the Air is one of few movies to truly get with the times, and actually get it right.
A gratifying music biopic that is surprisingly humble in its treatment of John Lennon
Just off the beaten track from Wolf Creek and Cape Fear is Rupert Glasson's promising feature debut Coffin Rock; a must-see destination for deftly crafted thrills and chills.

Like the pseudo biopic on Mandela, the rugby half is both shallow and generic, qualities echoed by the horrendously mawkish theme song 'Colorblind' that is enough to make Invictus seem like a parody of an inspirational film.
A film that shines only in short, erratic bursts. It can be an emotional film, a disturbing film, a romantic film, a funny film and a breathtaking film, but never a seamless blend of each.
Coating classic romanticism with breathtaking 3D visuals, Avatar transports us to another world for 162 minutes of sensory bliss.
Watching McCarthy's story unfold is a lot like listening to a brooding musician hold down the lowest key on a piano for two unrelenting hours.

I'm going to go out on a limb and say Planet 51 was written by a bunch of monkeys...who were trapped in a room with some typewriters. Surprisingly, the works of Shakespeare are the only texts they haven't blatantly ripped off.
Squeamishly forthright and deliberately rough-around-the-edges, Sattouf's film humorously captures the weird, wonderful and often humiliating stages of adolescence.
Arriving in the wake of the awfully mawkish Invictus and the overbearingly bleak The Road, Precious succeeds because it strikes a balance between the two emotional extremes.
movie_title: Precious: Based on the Novel Push by Sapphire (2009)

movie_review_blurb: Easily the most exhilarating lesson in racial politics you're ever likely to sit through.
Cleverly twisted, gut-wrenching Aussie thriller.
Grocery shopping is arguably a more novel experience than Robert Luketic's The Ugly Truth.
Should have been aborted.
A long cry from her typically one-dimensional heroine roles in films such as Wanted and Tomb Raider, Angelina Jolie proves she is more than just a gun-wielding sex symbol.
Lean on substance, but bustling with excitement; Death Race is entertainment in its most primitive form.
Knowing is a bit of a revelation. Against all odds, it's not actually half bad.
A joyless mess of a movie.
Takes the post-apocalyptic themes of Children of Men and blends it with the jaded morality of Lord of the Flies to questionable success
Bolt marks Disney's long awaited re-emergence as a top-dog in the world of animation.
There's still some kindred magic in the air, not to mention a healthy dose of humour, but Potter's sixth year is easily his darkest, most mature adventure to date.
movie_title: Harry Potter and the Half-Blood Prince (2009)

movie_review_blurb: Pays homage to the classic Western by staying true to genre conventions, but does so with a fresh set of eyes that gives the film a welcome place in a modern multiplex.
As with junk food, no matter how much you know it's bad for you, you can't help but enjoy it anyway.
An experience likened to repeatedly playing with a Whoopie Cushion for an hour and a half...
Falls shy of being either a captivating tale for kids or an enlightening documentary for adults.
The animation is superb, characters endearing, humour abundant and topical themes honestly and thoroughly explored.
Saw V? You'll wish you hadn't.
Unfunny, unoriginal and tedious - Mall Cop is successful only at living up to the standard set by past films that have begun with the words 'A Happy Madison Production'.
Takes immense pleasure in letting its audience in on nothing.
A mildly enjoyed engagement that simply wasn't meant to last.
Not only is it genuinely scary, it's also outrageously funny. And for once, it's intentional.
Bruno's quest to become the most famous Austrian star 'since Hitler' is shocking, vulgar and shamelessly defamatory. It's also downright hilarious.
Whilst it's not the masterpiece we so desperately wanted it to be, Australia still manages to be a good time at the cinema.
Angels and Demons is a lot like Limbo, a place that exists between cinematic heaven and hell where the audience is suspended for two and a half hours.
It's a case of 'he's behind you!' repeated ad nauseum, where sudden bursts of sound stand in for real scares.
Two and a half hours of epic robot battles, thunderous explosions and Megan Fox running in slow motion. Two of the three grow incredibly tiresome.
There's not much for audiences over the age of 10 to warm to during this third, and hopefully final, Ice Age.
movie_title: Ice Age: Dawn of the Dinosaurs (Ice Age 3) (2009)

movie_review_blurb: A comedy binge-fest you won't regret in the morning.
Every time this slow-burning thriller appears to be running out of wick, Anderson's screenplay drops in an unexpected twist with impeccable timing.
The choice of digital tends to only exacerbate the films many flaws. It even reveals the imperfections of Johnny Depp's face. Who wants to see that?

Unambitiously [believes] that only way to improve on the original is to add more of everything. More heroes! More villains! More CGI! And more Robert Downey Jr.! Surprisingly, the result isn't all bad.
Love the Beast is a solid film about car lovers, for car lovers. Unfortunately, I'm not one of them.
What makes Balibo essential viewing is that, on top of its past and present political significance, it also happens to be one of the most captivating and thrilling films in years.
If Twilight is the Vampire film for starry-eyed teenage girls, Let the Right One In is the Vampire film for everyone else.
Never comes close to captivating its audience like the game did before it.
Check the return policy for this Orphan.
A lively, yet tedious, assault on the senses.
movie_title: G.I. Joe: The Rise of Cobra (2009)

movie_review_blurb: An engaging and inspirational story about the spirit of survival, bravery and brotherhood.
Synder has achieved what many said was impossible; he has in-fact filmed the unfilmable, and arguably done so as well as anyone could have.
A stylish, engaging and complex thriller.
Whilst 3D glasses might mask this lapse of originality by putting it all in your face, from a standard visual plane, the creative potential of Verne's novel appears to be inexcusably wasted.
movie_title: Journey to the Center of the Earth (2008)

movie_review_blurb: Yes Man is proof that reverse psychology works; No, it's not worth seeing because, no, it's not that funny.
Lacks the Gothic coolness that made the original such an underground hit.
movie_title: Underworld: The Rise of the Lycans (2009)

movie_review_blurb: More concerned with recruiting the testosterone troubled boys of today than it is rewarding fans of yesteryear.
A 'what not to do' guide when making an action film.
Those next to me in the cinema staring blankly at the screen gave a remarkably similar performance to that of Reeves without even being aware of it.
movie_title: The Day the Earth Stood Still (2008)

movie_review_blurb: Brendan Fraser's boyish face usually oozes charisma, but here he just looks plain bored. Which is kind of how the audience looked too.
If it's not fast and furious automotive action you're after, hoping instead for a cohesive character driven plot, then you're more likely to just get furious pretty damn fast.
In a post WALL-E world, it's hard not to be slightly underwhelmed by Madagascar: Escape 2 Africa.
It's certainly tough viewing, but Rachel Ward's feature debut is a superbly executed and deeply affecting piece of Australian cinema.
One of the best sci-fi films of the last decade, and that's coming from someone who has never Trekked before.
Captivatingly told, dynamically directed and superbly acted; Slumdog Millionaire is near unfaultable.
Each bottom feeding joke manages to be more side-splitting than the last.
An over-long mish-mash of scarcely linked sub-plots...
It's hard to shake the feeling that this is merely a lesser rehash of Mendes' more accomplished film American Beauty.
A solid homage to one of the film industries unsung heroes.
Like being forced to sit through an overly long wedding video in the living room of a couple you hardly even know.
[Cruise] looks about as German as Jackie Chan would in a lederhosen.
A delightfully modest film that overcomes its narrative lulls with authentically crafted characters and astute observations of everyday life.
Initial intrigue turns into tedium and frustration as the plot heads into the territory of absurd.
I too wish this Mummy stayed dead and buried.
movie_title: The Mummy: Tomb of the Dragon Emperor (2008)

movie_review_blurb: With a commercially agreeable directorial style, Gus Van Sant continues his foray into provocative cinema with what is quite possibly his best film yet.
Alexandre Aja must have thought that just because he's basing a film around mirrors acting irrationally, he can proceed to remove logic from all aspects of the film.
Boasting a cracking cast and a deliciously clever script, State of Play is a polished political thriller not to be missed.
Diabetics steer clear; so awfully saccharine is the derivative romantic drama Letters to Juliet, it may induce a hyperglycemic coma.
Fails to live up to the high expectations involuntarily set by such reputable talent.
Rejoice! Hollywood have, at long last, made a video game adaptation that is not complete tripe.
movie_title: Prince of Persia: The Sands of Time (2010)

movie_review_blurb: If there's any pleasure to be had watching a movie like this, it's almost certainly of the guilty variety.
Before Hal Jordan's big-screen debut, I'd never heard of the guy. And now, having sat through the confused mess that is Green Lantern, I don't mind if I never hear of him again.
One of the longest advertisements for PETA I've seen since 101 Dalmatians. Only, you know, not nearly as much fun.
movie_title: Rise of the Planet of the Apes (2011)

movie_review_blurb: An affable Aussie dramedy that turns back the clock and pretends that the golden age of Australian cinema never ended.
She's not somewhat bad, she's not repentantly bad and she's certainly not sympathetically bad. Nope, she's just plain ol' bad. And that is a thing of rare beauty.
It hardly matters that Deathly Hallows Part 2 is neither the best film of the series, nor the perfect conclusion to it. It's what it represents that's significant. And that's the end of an era.
movie_title: Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows - Part 2 (2011)

movie_review_blurb: If you're looking for the Transformers 3 experience without having to actually endure through it, simply tip out your cutlery drawer onto a FHM centrefold whilst humming 'The Star-Spangled Banner'. Hey presto.
If you're going to set the standard in animation, however lofty it may be, you best be prepared to live up to it. And Cars 2, it pains me to say, does not.
Finding a balance between serious and silly is something The Troll Hunter does astonishingly well.
While the line between inspiration and imitation blurs, what remains crystal clear is that Super 8 has been made with nothing but the purest of intentions: to entertain.
In a sea of sloppy sequels (Pirates 4) and rote remakes (Hangover 2), X-men: First Class stands out for simply being something different -- good.
One could easily mistake this supposed blockbuster for a mockbuster. After all, it was co-written by one of the scribblers of the Scary Movie series.
Like an elephant parading on bubble wrap, The Tree of Life breaks new ground with every step. It's just a shame that some of those strides are more ponderous than they are profound.
The Guard is certainly good for a laugh or two, but those that are claiming it to be funnier than In Bruges are claiming things that aren't true.
Sure, it corrects many of the mistakes that made the last film god-awful, but a step up from god-awful is just awful without as much blasphemy.
movie_title: Pirates of the Caribbean: On Stranger Tides (2011)

movie_review_blurb: The tireless Carey makes for a deserving subject in this witty, warming and rousing documentary about a school's duty to inspire students to achieve greatness.
For once, the trailer for a new comedy didn't spoil the best bits. Unfortunately, that's because there aren't any.
The first hour is one outrageously hilarious catfight. It comes at a price, though, because the second is where the girls all kiss and make-up.
A mildly intriguing, yet ultimately detached and pitiless portrait of psychopathy.
A tremendously enjoyable trip to the movies, one that gets your blood pumping fast enough to keep your brain ticking.
Don't leave your brain at the door like other critics are suggesting, just hide it behind a beer helmet and gleefully guzzle Teh Stoopid away.
Much like the titular Brazilian city, Rio is a festive film, heavily favouring frivolity over anything more deep and meaningful.
'Happy' is a lovely, jovial word that becomes something quite vile and abhorrent when followed by the word 'Madison'.
Red Riding Hood clearly aims to scare, yet Hardwicke's direction is about as tense as a broken rubber band.

Statham has my respect for two reasons: 1) he's one of the few remaining action stars who isn't claiming his pension, and 2) he has yet to star in a Disney movie in which he must babysit projectile-vomiting children.
I'm sure there's an epic battle going on here, but it's hard to tell when the cameraman is too busy shaking off a swarm of angry bees to capture any of it.
A clean-cut piece of entertainment that delivers an invigorating and engaging high with no nasty side effects.
An exorcism movie in which all the scary bits have been exorcised.
This is a good ol' fashioned haunting, one with a tangible atmosphere, strong performances and plenty of skin-crawling scares.
Pulls more emotional punches than physical ones.
Ironically enough, it's the journey, not the destination, that makes these movies so damn fun.
It's too concerned with style to leave a lasting impression, yet it's also warming and witty enough to pass by without doing any harm.
In director Ridley Scott's take [of Robin Hood], what was green is now grey, lively now lethargic and merry now miserable.
The word 'unexpected' is a severe understatement when regarding the narrative genius of In Bruges.
Behind a truckload of red makeup is Ron Perlman, whose characterisation of the egocentric protagonist Hellboy, or Red as he prefers to be called, is once again the highlight of the film.
When Ted isn't funny, it isn't much of anything. It's the sip of water a stand-up comedian takes between jokes, leaving the audience to twiddle their thumbs as they wait for the next one.
It's not necessarily a bad movie, it's just half of a great one. And that's almost more disappointing.
The story twists and turns with popcorn-friendly propulsion, never letting things get too serious to invite narrative nit-picking, nor too silly to squander the suspense.
Perhaps if every Hollywood film featured the grand yet gloomy decadency of a Burton production, I'd be more inclined to get caught up on where his films go wrong. But they don't, so I won't.
Strikes a far more even tone than Bridesmaids, exploring emotional truths whilst maintaining a strong, but not suffocating, comedic edge.
Scarcely enough substance to pad out a short poem, let alone a feature film.
I found myself reveling in the silliness of what is, essentially, the most expensive B-movie ever made.
Forget the rum; it's the fun that's running dry in Aardman Animation's The Pirates! Band of Misfits.
This account of Snow White isn't about to be crowned the fairest of them all, but a vibrant visual palate and sweet sense of humour ensures that it's no bad apple either.
For a film rehashing a long-forgotten TV series and starring the sentient muscle Channing Tatum, 21 Jump Street is surprisingly good.
I'm not particularly proud of laughing at this vulgar cliché of a movie, but dammit, laugh I did.
The production design and visual effects are so standout, it threatens to betray the film's delightfully kitschy B-movie premise.
Almost as if the project was subject to a hostile takeover by Michael Bay, Chronicle goes so garishly gangbusters in its final third, you'd be forgiven for reaching for a pair of 3D glasses.
Twilight: Breaking Dawn - Part 2 is coming out later this year, right? So at least this will only be the 2nd worst vampire vs. werewolf movie of 2012.
It's a film that only deals in excess, so unless you're a deliriously happy person with a serious foot fetish, you'd best give Happy Feet Two a miss.
Matt Damon, a master of the ordinary, can create a rounded, convincing and utterly engaging character out of just about anyone, Benjamin Mee included.
A signature Spielbergian adventure that almost makes me wish the directing great would have another crack at reviving Indiana Jones again. Almost...
Spectacular. Bird knows how to film an action scene, and Cruise knows how to star in one. It's a winning combination.
A casual heist movie that's played for laughs, not smarts.
An introverted film about an extroverted subject, which is what makes it such a delicate, unique experience.

Although it's somewhat disheartening to see one of the biggest advocates for stop motion trade in their clay for computers, there's no denying that Aardman's distinctive fingerprints are all over this one.
Alexandre Dumas isn't merely turning in his grave, he's half way through re-enacting 'Thriller'.
When the most innovative thing about the film is that the camera now oscillates, one can't help but scoff at the miniscule amount of creativity that has been drizzled into this Halloween cash grab.
Sure, this Thing still has its moments, but they're nothing compared to that Thing.
With all the gross-out comedies of late, it's nice to be able to laugh aloud at a film that doesn't require a swear jar.
Given that it stars action drone Sam Worthington, you'll be wishing they called it 'Man off a Ledge' before long.
A fascinating, exhilarating and remarkably profound movie-going experience.
This is the kind of movie you'd want to watch with a rewind button handy. Actually, at 127 painfully paced minutes, a fast-forward button might help too.
Petri loses out to the cinema's air conditioner when it comes to delivering chills during the film's ineffective climax.
Paul W.S. Anderson has discovered his favourite new gimmick - slow motion. Had Afterlife played at full speed, it probably would have lasted all of 15 minutes. Wouldn't that have been nice.
Whoever says you need to think outside the box should think again, because Buried is nothing short of a minimalist masterpiece.
Let Me In mimics the mood and mastery of Alfredson’s original almost to the point where it's a shot for shot remake. Yes, it’s good. But only because the original was good to begin with.
Dinner for Schmucks belongs to that mangy breed of American comedy that confuses situations that are genuinely funny for situations that are agonisingly awkward.
Without question, these are the nicest looking hooters you'll ever see in a movie. Well, a movie with a PG rating.
movie_title: Legend of the Guardians: The Owls of Ga'Hoole (2010)

movie_review_blurb: Here is a film that doesn't just scrape the bottom of the barrel, it demands that you lick it.
Shyamalan tells the story like a syndicated news journalist, reporting events with detached direction and lifeless, plot-driven screenwriting.
Will Ferrell is like the North Atlantic Ocean of comedy, the link between black British absurdist humour and boisterous American slapstick.
If Blakeson wasn't so desperate to shock his audience, the suspense he establishes early on might not have been so quick to join Miss. Creed in disappearing.
The Sorcerer's Apprentice is essentially what would happen if The Mummy took a wrong turn at Hogwarts and ended up at a Dungeons and Dragons convention.
Not since 2008's Oscar winner Slumdog Millionaire has pleasure and pain come together so beautifully.
As far as cheesy, sexist and violent B-movies go, Piranha 3D is a blast.
Salt doesn't mess around trying to be funny or romantic, instead focusing solely on the one thing that counts: pulse-pounding action.
Although it's full of wasted potential, Red is a prime example of a mediocre film elevated by raw star power.
As is the case with most films dedicated to appeasing short attention spans, Tomorrow struggles to register on an emotional level.
Director Jon Chu is, to lesser acclaim, a modern day Busby Berkeley; he's a choreographer, not a storyteller.
Natali [takes] his film down some dark and disturbing paths, and even if you're not overly keen about the destination, you have to commend him for daring to go there.
This lazily plotted and performed political snoozer has to be one of the most disappointing films I've seen all year.
McKay is magnificent [as Welles]. Not for a moment did I doubt that this was the man who went on to make Citizen Kane.
And [Nolan] said, "let there be originality", and there was originality. He called it Inception and audiences and critics alike saw that it was good.
Feminists, look away now.
Wax on, nod off.
Living up to its name, The Waiting City rewards patience. The film's initial unevenness is remedied by a captivating second half full of heart.
I left the cinema feeling as though I deserved a t-shirt that read 'I survived the Eclipse'
One sequence alone has more heart, humour, intellect and hair-raising thrills than most films - live-action or animated - have overall.
The opening mid-air shootout is edgy, funny and clouded in question-raising mystique. It's everything the film that follows is not.
Silence has rarely been so telling.
Be it documentary or mockumentary, art of graffiti, there's no denying that Exit Through the Gift Shop is damn good cinema.
Favouring style over substance is generally a deal-breaker in movies like this, but then again, it's not often you see style this substantial.
There's a lot to like, yet The Social Network lacks a strong emotional core that is integral to making a good drama truly great.
Heigl and Kutcher's romance has about as much crackle as a bowl of soggy Rice Bubbles.

The filmmakers continue to regurgitate the same pile of puke each and every year for us to lap up. Sure, those chewed chunks of bile-soaked carrot are now in "eye-popping" 3D, but that certainly doesn't make them taste any better.
And I am incredibly bored.
The film degenerates into a repetitive game of cat and mouse in which Roger Sterling chases Jason Bourne through a bunch of magical doors.
A squeamishly self-aware bloodbath in which Lola, superbly portrayed by Robin McLeavy with hellish zeal, reveals her ambition to be the next Hannibal Lecter.
It's the questions that ultimately keep Unknown afloat, regardless of how silly the answers might be.
There's a light at the end of Rabbit Hole that makes this tearful trek worthwhile.
It doesn't matter how disarming Franco's single-handed performance is; there is simply not enough dramatic meat on the bones of Ralston's true story to distract us from where it is heading.
[It's] tragic alright, but not in the same way as the Bard intended.

There's a primal intensity, both adrenal and emotional, flowing through Tillman Jr's frenetic direction and Johnson's gritty performance that suggests there's more going on under the hood than the stock fittings let on.
Eastwood's weepy depiction of the 'here' is just as dull and tedious as his superficial exploration of the 'after'.
Although it mightn't be Coen in quirk, it certainly is Coen in quality.
There's just enough novelty, action and comedy in the tank to see this film teeter across the finish line, even if it does cough and splutter for much of the journey.
Catfish reveals in the most surprising of ways why a social network created by a lonely teenage introvert is, in a word, fishy.
As they say about train wrecks, it's impossible to look away.
About as much fun as standing in line at Customs for hours after a long-haul flight.
If I had to dig for praise, it's impressive that Reitman manages to get the 5'2" Portman and 6'3" Kutcher in the same frame.
[Steve] Antin hasn't really written Burlesque, he has merely spooned the story out of a can labelled 'Instant Musical: Just add eyeliner.'
The darker atmosphere and real-world locales makes this the most mature and humanistic entry to date, but it's hard not to miss the warmth and whimsy that has been left behind.
movie_title: Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows - Part 1 (2010)

movie_review_blurb: Schindler's List was funnier than this.
A good example of what can visually be achieved on a tight budget, but an even better example of why filmmaking should be left to filmmakers.
Red Hill only truly works when it retains a hard edge and a straight face. So why does Hughes insist on blowing so many raspberries?
The Last Exorcism is a rare reminder that the genre label "horror" derives from the word horrifying, not horrible.
It's never quite slap-your-knees hilarious, but Megamind will still have you smiling from dimple to dimple for every one of its 95 minutes.
It's bad enough that it took four screenwriters to ineptly rehash Planes, Trains and Automobiles, but it's even worse that they've only managed to come up with one new joke each.
Tron: Legacy looks like the bathroom of a trendy nightclub.
The tagline "Nobody baby but you and me" says it perfectly; when Gosling and Williams on screen, nobody else matters. If not Oscars, they will win over your heart. And possibly break it.
Not only tolerable, but actually - *gasp* - enjoyable. [...] The 3D is better employed here than it was in Tron: Legacy.
Somewhere features dead-on-the-inside people looking pensively into their bowls of pasta. Some call this reality, I call it bloody boring.

David Seidler writes in a way that Aaron Sorkin of The Social Network couldn't; he successfully balances truth and entertainment, injecting a keen sense of humour without costing the film its humanity or credibility.
By playing on our intrinsic fear of the unknown, Monsters turns out to be far more convincing, compelling and unnerving than the likes of Skyline where the aliens are constantly in the limelight.

Michôd never freely opens up as to what is going on in the larger world, opting instead to give hints and clues and allowing the audience to create its own interpretation as to why things fell to pieces.
A wonderful portrait of Ebert, who was a populist of film criticism and also a tremendous critic himself.
It should be a match made in heaven, but sadly, the film adaptation of "Jersey Boys" doesn't live up to the success that the property previously enjoyed.
"Korengal" doesn't have the immediacy of "Restrepo," but it's frequently affecting, as well as being a remembrance of just how young the people are we send into harm's way.
I appreciate Haggis' body of work, but in this case, his vision may have gotten in the way of his perspective.
Basically, it's the cinematic equivalent of purchasing an entire album, enjoying the entire thing, but over time realizing that you only care for about half the songs.
Almost everyone who testifies - including Sylvester Stallone, Tom Arnold and Michael Douglas - agrees that he's the greatest thing since sliced bread.
movie_title: Supermensch: The Legend of Shep Gordon (2014)

movie_review_blurb: The production design is sharp and unique, though the movie itself is not without its flaws.
There are some solid ideas, but there are so many superfluous storylines that the movie's lovely moments - and they are there - get covered up and hidden.
Rarely do you see a film with just two characters, but Amalric and Seigner have so much control over themselves that they keep you entranced throughout the entire 96 minutes.
The acting is stronger than the rest of the film itself, which sports far too much shaky camera work and a conclusion that is obviously foreshadowed by the appearance of a gun early on.
Wouldn't it be funny if a middle-age couple had to track down their sex tape? Sure, that's not a terrible concept, but everything that follows doesn't seem even slightly well considered.
You've undoubtedly never seen anything like this before.

movie_review_blurb: The photography is superior to the dialogue.
Miss West gives a highly amusing performance.
Even when the picture is viewed without the distortions of the Marxist critical lenses, it emerges as a work of unusual beauty and emotional exaltation.
Running a solid hundred minutes, the film first shocks and stimulates the imagination, and then, lacking the dramatic skill to refresh its audiences, becomes steadily duller.
Adults are better off rewatching Hotel Transylvania (2012) or The Incredibles (2004), whose dysfunctional families are more human than this one.
The movie builds up so much goodwill through its effervescent humour and spectacular set pieces that, like Garmadon, it is easy to look past its shortcomings.
Too many side characters and too little character development aside, this feature-length car commercial will please petrolheads.
In a nutshell, this crowd-pleaser has some bite, but families craving something more filling should hunt elsewhere.
movie_title: The Nut Job 2: Nutty by Nature (2017)

movie_review_blurb: This is the Smurfs' first fully animated CGI outing. It is not only respectful of the source material, but also charmingly pretty in parts.

Zero Days is more than just, as a source puts it, "a cool spy story". It is also a cautionary tale of the dangers of secrecy and a clarion call for an honest discussion on cyber weapons and their lethal potential.
If Rock Dog were a band, they would be more opening act than headliner.
Katy Perry's sugary sweet wonderland is a hit with her fans, but it also makes for an inspiring movie for those who might have never heard her music.
Nothing seems to get short shrift, including Nas' parentage, childhood, education, and musical beginnings. Yet, at a brisk 75 minutes, the film doesn't overstay its welcome.
